Intro to Machine Learning

Introduction¶

Definition¶

There are multiple definitions of machine learning in different publications. But the general idea behind machine learning is that it is a technique in which the computer learns from the data and the performs a task without explicitly being programmed.

For formally the definition that describes machine learning best is this.

A computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some task T and some performance measure P, if its performance on T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.

Tom Mitchell, 1997

The most basic example of machine learning is the of detecting whether an email is spam or not (ham). The system uses existing data from the already existing emails which the user has manually labeled as spam and uses it to train itself. Now when a new email arrives it checks whether the email is similarly to that of already detected spam mail using various feature like likely words used in title, so same email id etc. Then decides (predicts) whether the new email is spam or not.

Uses of Machine learning¶

Why use machine learning in the first place? Under what situations does machine learning helps?

Preventing Complex Rule.¶

Let's take the email spam detection example. Suppose we have to build an spam filter using traditional programing approach. Then the ideal candidate would be to write a series of conditions using if else branch. For example, if title of email contains words like "free", "amazing", "4U" or else if email is from a list of already identified email address etc. But as the spammer keeps updating his spamming technique then we will have to add new rule to the list. An soon the rule become unmanageable and complex.

Using machine learning we can let the system learn the rules on itself by comparing the data of existing classified email and keep learning on new email which were wrongly classified as safe but were actually spam.

No traditional Solution.¶

Some computing problem are too difficult to solved by traditional procedure/rules approach. Consider the problem of speech recognition. To develop speech recognition software we would have to check each audio with combination of multiple world from a certain language and also multiple accents. Which is not possible to code.

The best solution is to write a algorithm which learns on itself.

Discovering insight from data.¶

Machine learning can also help human learn insight from the data. Onces a machine learning algorithm has learned rule/patterns on itself then a human can inspect what the system has learned and get more insight from the data.

Applying Machine learning to discover patterns from huge data is called data mining.

Types of Machine learning¶

Machine learning algorithms are broadly classified into three different categories.

  • Whether or not they are trained with human supervision (supervised, unsupervised, semisupervised, and Reinforcement Learning)
  • Whether or not they can learn incrementally on the fly (online versus batch learning)
  • Whether they work by simply comparing new data points to known data points, or instead detect patterns in the training data and build a predictive model, much like scientists do (instance-based versus model-based learning or parametric versus non-parametric algorithm)

Supervised and Unsupervised Learning¶

Machine learning algorithms can be classified on the type of supervision required during the training phase.

Supervised Learning¶

In Supervised Learning, the data is supplied with label for training the algorithm.

Example of Supervised Learning is classification (Categorizing data) and regression (Predicting value from a given feature).

Unsupervised Learning¶

In Unsupervised learning the training data is unlabeled. The algorithm discover patterns or learns from data on it self.

Examples includes, Clustering algorithm to find unknown groups in data, Visualization algorithm to give a 2D or 3D visualization of data or Association Learning who's goal is to find unknown rules/association form a given data.

Semisupervised Learning¶

Some algorithm are combination of Supervised learning and Unsupervised learning.

The best example of this is Google Photos. The algorithm behind photos takes multiple photos and recognizes same person in multiple photos (Unsupervised) and then asks you to name that person and the assigned name to each present and future photo of that person with that name (Supervised).

Reinforcement Learning¶

In Reinforcement learning there is agent which performs some action in the environment and then receives feedback. The feedback is either negative or positive. And based on that feedback the agent either continues doing the think it is doing or improves its action.

Example is a game placing agent. For a chess playing agent the algorithm will play multiple games with itself and learn from the moves which result in higher score. Thus improving the moves as training improves over time.

Online Vs Batch Learning¶

Other category is how the system learning. Some algorithms keeps learning continuously as the data is feed into the system. Example would be stock market prediction algo. The data stream is continuous for the algorithm and the learning of the system never stops. Such system is called Online system.

For some system the learning is incremental. Example can be Google speech recognition algorithm. Onces the model is trained the model is updated on the Android phones. And the team at Google would record more audios from different language and accents and the train the model and then later update the model again from the Android devices.

Instance/Non-parametric Vs Model Based/Parametric Learning¶

Other way is how the algorithm learns from the data. One method is Instance based also called as non-parametric. In this method the algorithm has access to all the data and whenever a new instance is to categorized or predicted it check the other instances in the data which are similarly to that of new instance and assign the new instance to the same group of data or predict the value of new instance based on value of similar instance. Example would be spam detection, if a new email is 95% similar to existing spam email then possibility the email is spam.

Another way is that system build a model (equation) from the data and then use that model to predict the value for new instance. Example would be linear regression which tries to fit a line through the data and whenever a new instance is to be predicted it check where on the line the new instance fits and then predicts the value accordingly. This type of algorithms are called model based or parametric based learning algorithm.

Challenges in Machine Learning¶

There are some challenges with applying machine learning to get the right desire outcome from the data. Some of them are given below.

Insufficient Quantity of Training Data.¶

When there is less data to train data the model would not fit to the ideal production data and thus the outcome would not be that accurate. It is sample as taking a small sample space and predicting the parameters of the population.

Nonrepresentative Training Data.¶

Training data much be a good representative of future unknown instance. But the algorithm see a new data which is nothing similar to what it has seen in the training phase then the outcome is uncertain.

Poor quality data.¶

Missing or bad data in training can also affect the outcome of the algorithm on live data.

Irrelevant Features.¶

Not choosing a proper or relevant feature to predict the outcome will surely degrade the performance of the system. For example, will detecting spam email taking consideration whether it is raining will give curtain result.

Overfitting Training Data.¶

Ever data has some noise in it, even training data. So creating a model which predicts the exact value for training data set is not a good idea that it has selected parameters which are too closely related to training data. Such model will performance badly on production data as the noise level will vary in production data.

One example would be trying to fit a function to every point in linear regression by creating a model of same degree as that of number of training sample. Then the model would also fit to the noise in the data and thus perform very poorly on the real dataset.

Underfitting Training Data.¶

Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to learn the underlying structure of the data. For example using linear regression on a quadratic data.

One example is suppose the dataset graph is following a quadratic trace and we use linear regression and try to fit a straight line through the data. Which will lead into bad prediction of the data.

Testing and Validation¶

Onces training of the machine learning model is done how can we be sure that the model/algorithm will work on new unseen data inputs. The only way to make sure of this is to split the data into two sets. One set for training the model and the other to test the model. Usually the percentage is 80% as training data and 20% test data.

But there is a problem with this method. The problem is we use training data to train our system and then if the performance on test data fail we might over fit the model to the training data set. So another common practice is to divide the data into three sets training, validation and test.

We train the model on training set so the model fits to the training dataset. Then we give it an unseen data set (validation set) and allow the model to change its parameter to based on validation set. And then we finally calculate the actual performance on the final test set.

Another practice to avoid wasting too much training data in validation set is to use cross-validation: the training set is split into complementary subsets, and each model is trained against a different combination of these subsets and validated against the remaining parts.

Regression¶

Regression is a supervised, model based, batch algorithm. The algorithm creates a model/hypothesis from the data and then predict the value of new instance based on the learned hypothesis.

The flow of the regression algorithm is shown in the diagram below.

The learning algorithm is given training data $X$ where $X$ can be a single input data or multiple input data. Input data is also called as feature and the output that we are trying to predict is called the target. A transitional example, would be to predict the prices of a house in a given area. In such case the prices of house might depend upon multiple parameters like size of the house, number of bedrooms, year constructed etc thus these become the feature of our training data set and the value we are trying to predict, price of the house, becomes the target.

The hypothesis $H(X)$ is a function of our feature which return the predict value of the target ($Y$). Given a training data to the learning algorithm it tries to build a hypothesis based on our initial assumption of the data. If the data is linear we will try to fit the a straight line through the data and then use the straight line to predict the price based on where the new feature meets the line. In such case the hypothesis will be a line function $Y=\theta_0 + X\theta_1$ where $\theta_0$ and $\theta_1$ are called the parameters. And the goal of the learning algorithm is to find the best values for the parameters will reduce our error in predicting the target value of a new unseen feature.

Linear Regression / Multiple Regression¶

One example of regression algorithm is "Linear Regression". Lets take an example.

stockprices.csv

Above is a stock prices of Google and Amazon from 04/02/2015 to 03/02/2016. We think that the there is an correlation between the stock prices of both of the stock prices. So we want to predict the price of stock value of Google (target) given stock value of Amazon (feature).

First lets see how this data looks.

%matplotlib inline

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

CSV_FILE_PATH = '../../static/raw/notes/machine-learning/intro-to-machine-learning/stockprices.csv'

# Read CSV file
training_data = pd.read_csv(CSV_FILE_PATH, delimiter='\t')

# Plot data
plt.scatter(training_data.amazon, training_data.google)
plt.xlabel('Amazon')
plt.ylabel('Google')
plt.show()

As we can see from the data there is strong correlation between the data. I data almost follows a linear pattern. If we could fit a line through the data we can predict the price of stock price of Google given stock price of Amazon.

So the equation of line is given by $y=mx+c$ were $m$ is the slope of the line and $c$ is the y intercept of the line. Using this equation we can draw any line a 2D plane. And our data is also two dimensional (Amazon and Google price). To be consistent with machine learning algorithm we will write the equation as follows, $y=\theta_0 + x\theta_1$ where $\theta_0$ and $\theta_1$ are our parameters. So the goal of the linear regression algorithm is to find the best possible value for $\theta_0$ and $\theta_1$ such that we get a line which perfectly fits the data. Thus our hypothesis in this example can be written as.

$$ h(x) = h_\theta(x) = \theta_0 + x \theta_1 $$

The above definition get a little big and complex when we start working with multiple parameters and features. So we can reduce the definition using some vector notions.

We can denote the parameters of the algorithm as vector of $M$ rows (also called as parameter vector) where $M$ denotes the number of training data (number of rows in csv for this example). And let $N$ denote the total number of features. Then

$$ \theta = \begin{bmatrix} \theta_0 \\ \theta_1 \\ - \\ - \\ \theta_N \end{bmatrix} $$

And if we can denote features such $x_1, x_2, x_3, ... , x_N$ and let $x_0=1$ then we can write the feature as a vector of $N$ rows (also called as feature vector) as follows.

$$ X = \begin{bmatrix} x_0 \\ x_1 \\ - \\ - \\ x_N \end{bmatrix} $$

Thus our Hypothesis function becomes.

$$ h(x) = \begin{bmatrix} \theta_0, \; \theta_1, \; -, \; -, \; \theta_N \end{bmatrix} * \begin{bmatrix} x_0 \\ x_1 \\ - \\ - \\ x_N \end{bmatrix} = \theta^T X $$

Cost function¶

How do we decide what values we use for our parameters ($\theta$) so that our line fits perfectly to the data?

If we think what we are trying to do here is we already have some know values of our target $Y$ (Google stock price) for some know feature value $X$ (Amazon stock price). And we want to select some value for our parameters ($\theta$) such that the value of our hypothesis function ($h(x)$) is as close to the value of our target $Y$. So how we decide which value of parameter is good or bad.

One way to do this is by calculating the predicted value $Y$ for know $X$ and then taking difference between them to see how are they from each other. Then the mean of the differences will give us an average of how far are the predicted values from the actual values.

$$ \frac{1}{M}\sum_{i=0}^M (h(x^{(i)}) - y^{i}) $$

Where $x^{(i)}$ denotes the $i^{th}$ feature and $y^{(i)}$ denotes the $i^{th}$ target value.

But the problem here is that some difference would be positive and others would be negative and they might cancel out each other. To overcome this we take the square of the difference of individual instance and then add them, thus giving us.

$$ \frac{1}{M} \sum_{i=0}^M (h_\theta(x^{(i)}) - y^{i})^2 $$

This above way to calculating the error in the prediction is called the Mean Square Error.

We can generalize the above equation as a function of $\theta$ as follows.

$$ J(\theta) = \frac{1}{M} \sum_{i=0}^M (h_\theta(x^{(i)}) - y^{i})^2 $$

The above function $J(\theta)$ is generally called the "cost function". And the goal of the learning algorithm is to choose value of our parameters ($\theta$) and minimize $J(\theta)$ such that $J$ gets as close as possible to zero ($J \to 0$).

But for linear generation we multiple the function by $\frac{1}{2}$ so to simply further calculation (in gradient descent). So for linear regression the cost function is defined as below.

$$ J(\theta) = \frac{1}{2M} \sum_{i=0}^M (h_\theta(x^{(i)}) - y^{i})^2 $$ 
%matplotlib inline

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from mpl_toolkits import mplot3d
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

CSV_FILE_PATH = '../../static/raw/notes/machine-learning/intro-to-machine-learning/stockprices.csv'

# Cost function
def get_cost(amazon, google, theta_0, theta_1):
    # Hypothesis function
    predicted_values = amazon * theta_1 + theta_0

    # Difference between predicted value and target
    difference = google - predicted_values
    
    # Square of difference
    sum_of_square_difference = difference ** 2

    # Sum of square of difference
    sum_of_difference = np.sum(sum_of_square_difference)
    
    # sum_of_difference multipled by 1/2m.
    return sum_of_difference * (1/(2*len(amazon)))


# Read CSV file
training_data = pd.read_csv(CSV_FILE_PATH, delimiter='\t')

# Read CSV file
training_data = pd.read_csv(CSV_FILE_PATH, delimiter='\t')

# Normalize Data
amazon = (training_data.amazon-400)/(1000-400)
google = (training_data.google-400)/(1000-400)

# Theta values
theta_0_values = np.arange(-2.0, 2.0, 0.1)
theta_1_values = np.arange(-2.0, 2.0, 0.1)

# Compute Cost functon
xx, yy = np.meshgrid(theta_0_values, theta_1_values)
costs = np.array([get_cost(amazon, google, a, b) for a, b in zip(np.ravel(xx), np.ravel(yy))])

# Plot cost function
fig = plt.figure()
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')

Z = costs.reshape(xx.shape)
ax.plot_surface(xx, yy, Z)

ax.set_xlabel('Theta 0')
ax.set_ylabel('Theta 1')
ax.set_zlabel('Cost Function')

plt.show()

In the above diagram we have plotted the cost function of our data with linear hypothesis. As we can see the cost the function is near zero when $\theta_0$ is between $0.5$ and $1.0$ and $\theta_1$ between $-1$ and $-0.5$.

Gradient Descent¶

We have seen how the we can compute the ideal value of the parameters from plotting data. But how do we compute the value of the parameters algorithmically?

There are multiple ways of doing so but the most common way of doing it is "Gradient Descent".

The idea of gradient descent is simple, we select some random point on our cost function plot and then check our surrounding in 360 degree to see going in which direction will help us reduce the value of function.

In the above diagram we can see that we start from a random point uphill and then we check in which direction should we go down hill and then move it in that direction and continue the steps until we reach a local minimum where there is no place to go. And that becomes our value of parameters.

So lets say we are at some random point on the function, how do we decide in which direction should be go to minimize the function. One way to do this is to take derivative of the function.

As shown in above diagram, if we take derivate of a function at a particular point it would give us the slope of the line which is tangent to the function at that point. Because derivate is given as rate of change which is called as $\frac{f(x+h) - f(x)}{\Delta h}$ where $\Delta h$ represents small change in $x$. When $\Delta h$ is very small the value of derivate is same as the slope of the tangent of the point $\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}$. Also the slope of the line gives us the direction of the steepness. As seen from the diagram if the slope is positive then we must decrease the value of parameter and if it is negative then we need to increase the value of our function to minimize the cost function.

Thus to calculate our next value of $\theta$ we can use the following formulae.

$$ \theta := \theta - \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} J(\theta) $$

Derivation of partial derivative of the cost function goes as follows.

Lets find derivate for $\theta = \theta_0$

$$ \begin{align*} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} J(\theta) &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)})^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)})^2 \tag{Scalar multiplication} \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)})^2 \tag{Sum Rule} \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} 2 (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \tag{Chain Rule} \\ &= \frac{2}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} (\theta_0 + x^{(i)}\theta_1 + ... + x^{(n)} \theta_n - y^{(i)}) \tag{By definition} \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} J(\theta) &= \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \\ \end{align*} $$

In the last step as we are taking derivate with respect to $\theta_0$ everything is constant expect $\theta_0$ and $\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0} \theta_0 = 1$. Thus giving the value of derivate as $1$.

Now for some other value of $\theta_j$ expect $\theta_0$.

$$ \begin{align*} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j} J(\theta) &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j} \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)})^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)})^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)})^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} 2 (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \\ &= \frac{2}{2m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j} (\theta_0 + x^{(1)}\theta_1 + ... + x^{(n)} \theta_n - y^{(i)}) \\ \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j} J(\theta) &= \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) x^{(j)} \\ \end{align*} $$

In the last step as we are taking derivate with respect to $\theta_i$ everything is constant expect $\theta_i$. Thus the equation becomes $\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_i} \theta_ix^{(i)} = x^{(i)}$.

Thus our final equation for calculation the next value of $\theta$ becomes.

$$ \begin{aligned} \theta_0 &:= \theta_0 - \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \\ \theta_j &:= \theta_j - \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) x^{(j)} \end{aligned} $$

To give a manual control over the step size given by the slope of the line (derivative). We generally multiply the derivate by a number called as learning rate and denoted by $\alpha$. By increasing the $\alpha$ we can increase the number of step the next $\theta$ jumps to and opposite if we reduce alpha. So the final equation that is generally used in practice is as follows.

$$ \begin{aligned} \theta_0 &:= \theta_0 - \frac{\alpha}{m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \\ \theta_j &:= \theta_j - \frac{\alpha}{m} \sum_{i=0}^{m} (h_{\theta}^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) x^{(j)} \end{aligned} $$

Choosing the learning rate must be done properly, because if the learning rate is chosen very high the the algorithm will take forever to reach the local minimum. And if the learning rate is chosen very high the algorithm will keep jumping from positive to negative slope and never reach the local minimum. Best idea to check cost function by starting with learning rate as $0.5, 0.1, 0.01, 0.001$ etc.

Types of gradient descent.¶

When using gradient descent in practical scenario there are computational challenges. Which include the time it take to calculate the next value of $\theta$ or the amount of data which can used for computing at a single instances of time. So to overcome such challenges there variation of the algorithm have been developed.

  • Batch Gradient descent.
  • Stochastic Gradient Descent.
  • Mini Batch Gradient Descent
  • Coordinate Gradient Descent.
Batch Gradient descent.¶

The algorithm we saw above is the batch gradient descent. In which to find the next value of parameters the entire training set is needed. Then for next iteration again the parameters are updated and entire training data is used to calculate the next value of the parameter. Each such iteration is generally called to epoch. This will result in accurate values for our parameter but is very slow as we iterate over our entire training set.

Stochastic Gradient Descent.¶

To work on drawback of batch gradient descent. Stochastic take one instance of training data at a time and adjusts the parameter based on the outcome of a single training instance. It will not result in an accurate parameter value but it will be quicker as only one iteration over training set is required.

Mini Batch Gradient Descent¶

Mini Batch algorithm is a combination of batch and stochastic gradient descent. Initially the training data is divided into multiple smaller sets generally between 50 to 200 instances. And for each iteration we choose and random set from the sets of training data we partition earlier. Mini batch algorithm is more faster but less accurate than batch gradient decent and less faster but more accurate than stochastic gradient descent.

Coordinate Gradient Descent.¶

Another variation of gradient descent is Coordinate. In this algorithm instead of computing gradient decent on each feature we choose only one feature at a time for a single iteration. The and move in the direction of slope for that feature. The choose of feature can be round robin or random. But the idea behind it is that if we choose single feature at a time we will eventually reach the global minium of all the feature.

Closed - Form solution¶

Another way to minimize the cost function is to take the derivative of the cost function and set it to zero. Because the function will have a zero derivative at local minimum. And then we can use that derivative to compute the value of parameters which minimizes the cost function.

To calculate the derivative of cost function we will introduce some notions.

Let $X$ denote matrix ($X \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{N*M}$). Where $N$ is the number of feature and $M$ be the number of training samples. $X$ contains all training samples.

Let $\theta$ be a vector of parameters and $y$ be a vector of target values.

Then we can write cost function as follows.

$$ J(\theta) = \frac{1}{2m} (X\theta - y)^T (X\theta - y) $$

We take square of difference as before by using inner product of the difference.

We can simplify the equation as follows.

$$ \begin{aligned} J(\theta) &= \frac{1}{2m} (X\theta - y)^T (X\theta - y) \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} ( \; ( \; (X\theta)^T - y^T \; ) (X\theta - y) \; ) \\ J(\theta) &= \frac{1}{2m} (\; (X\theta)^TX\theta - (X\theta)^T y - y^TX\theta -y^Ty \;) \\ \end{aligned} $$

Now here $X\theta$ and $y$ are vectors so it doesn't matter in which order we multiple them as long as the dimension matches. So $(X\theta)^Ty = y^TX\theta$. Thus our equation becomes,

$$ J(\theta) = \frac{1}{2m} (\; (X\theta)^TX\theta - 2(X\theta)^T y -y^Ty \;) $$

Now we take partial derivative of the function with respect to $\theta$. Derivate of a matrix/vector is similar to that of scalar quantity.That is when we take derivative of a vector/matrix we take derivative of each individual element of the matrix.

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial J}{\partial\theta} &= \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} \frac{1}{2m} (\; (X\theta)^TX\theta - 2(X\theta)^T y -y^Ty \;) \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} (\; (X\theta)^TX\theta - 2(X\theta)^T y -y^Ty \;) \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} (\; \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}( (X\theta)^TX\theta ) - \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} 2(X\theta)^T y - \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} y^Ty \;) \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} (\; \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}( (X\theta)^TX\theta ) - \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} 2(X\theta)^T y \;) \\ \frac{\partial J}{\partial\theta} &= \frac{1}{2m} (\; \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}( X^T\theta^TX\theta ) - 2X^T y \;) \\ \end{aligned} $$

We if we consider the first equation.

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}( X^T\theta^TX\theta ) &= X^T X \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} (\theta^T \theta) \end{aligned} $$

We have a rule of derivate of vectors.

$$ \frac{\partial x^Tx}{\partial x} = 2 x $$

We can understand the intuition behind the rule as follows,

$$ \begin{aligned} x &= \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ - \\ - \\ x_n \end{bmatrix}\\ x x^T &= \begin{bmatrix} (x_1)^2 \\ (x_2)^2 \\ - \\ - \\ (x_n)^2 \end{bmatrix} \\ \frac{\partial x x^T}{\partial x} &= \begin{bmatrix} 2x_1 \\ 2x_2 \\ - \\ - \\ 2x_n \end{bmatrix} \\ \frac{\partial x x^T}{\partial x} &= 2\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ - \\ - \\ x_n \end{bmatrix} \\ \end{aligned} $$

Thus our derivation becomes.

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta}( X^T\theta^TX\theta ) &= X^T X \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta} (\theta^T \theta) \\ &= X^T X 2 \theta \end{aligned} $$

Substituting the above value in derivative of $J(\theta)$ we get.

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial J}{\partial\theta} &= \frac{1}{2m} (\; X^T X 2 \theta - 2X^T y \;) \\ &= \frac{1}{2m} (\; 2X^T X \theta - 2X^T y \;) \end{aligned} $$

Now to find the local minimum of the function we set derivate to zero.

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial J}{\partial\theta} = \frac{1}{2m} (\; 2X^T X \theta - 2X^T y \;) &= 0 \\ 2X^T X \theta - 2X^T y &= 0 \\ 2X^T X \theta &= 2X^T y \\ X^T X \theta &= X^T y \\ \end{aligned} $$

Now assuming that $(X^TX)$ is invertible. We can write.

$$ \theta = (X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty $$

The above equation is called "normal equation" or the "closed form equation". Which can be used to directly compute the value of the parameters.

Closed form linear regression is only useful if number of samples is less than $1000$ because it involves matrix multiplication which is an $O(n^3)$ costly operation. For bigger data the normal iterative gradient descent is preferred.

Probabilistic interpretation of linear regression¶

Earlier we have seen linear regression form an analytical perspective. We also used sum of error square without understand why did we square it or not used absolute value of the difference raise to some other number for example $4$.

Maximizing likelihood function.¶

In machine learning we are generally given a set of know $X$ features and $Y$ target value we try to build a model. We can look this from another perspective of probability.

In general theory of probability we usually have a probability distribution form a particular dataset and then given an input $x$ we can tell what is the probability of getting $x$ when we do a particular experiment. The most common probability distribution is a gaussian distribution also called as normal distribution. Show below.

Here is we know value of $x$ let say $x=0$ and we have the normal distribution above with mean $\mu=0$ and standard deviation $\delta^2=1$ we can tell the probability of $x=0$ as $P(x=0)=0.4$.

In machine learning contest, we are generally given the $x$ and the $y$ and we need to find a distribution which fits the given $x$ and $y$. In other words we are have value of $x$ and it probability $P(x)$ and we need to find a value for the parameter of distribution $\mu$ and $\delta^2$ such that the distribution matches the value perfectly.

Shown below is number of distribution with different values of mean and standard deviation and data.

We denote this operation as the likelihood function of $y$ given $\mu$ and $\delta$. Denoted by $\mathcal{L}(y|\mu,\theta)$ is state that what is the likelihood of getting the $y$ we have observed in the data for a given $\mu$ and $\delta^2$. And in machine learning our goal is to find the $\mu$ and the $\delta^2$ which gives the maximum value for the likelihood of the function. To this we maximize the function $\mathcal{L}(y|\mu, \theta)$ with respect to $\mu$.

Let take an example. We have following dataset with us $Y = (9, 9.5, 11)$ and our goal is to find a distribution which fit the our distribution correctly. And let assume that the dataset follows a normal distribution with following probability function given $\mu$ and $\delta^2$.

$$ P(x;\mu,\delta^2) = \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} exp \left ( - \frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \right ) $$

Now to find the likelihood of the dataset we take the joint probability of the function.

$$ \begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(y;\mu,\delta^2) &= \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} exp \left ( - \frac{(9 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \right ) \\ \times& \; \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} exp \left ( - \frac{(9.5 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \right ) \\ \times& \; \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} exp \left ( - \frac{(11 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \right ) \end{aligned} $$

Now since the normal distribution is a convex function, we find the maximum of the likelihood of the function by taking derivative with respect to $\mu$ and substituting it as zero. But taking derivate of multiplication of distribution function is a difficult, so we take the derivative of the $\log$ of the likelihood function because $\log$ is a monotonic function if $x$ increase $\log(x)$ increases and viz versa. Thus taking log of the function it comes as follows.

$$ \begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(y;\mu,\delta^2) &= \log \left ( \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} exp \left ( - \frac{(9 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \right ) \right ) \\ \times& \log \left ( \; \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} exp \left ( - \frac{(9.5 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \right ) \right ) \\ \times& \log \left ( \; \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} exp \left ( - \frac{(11 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \right ) \right ) \\ &= \log \left ( \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} \right ) - \frac{(9 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \\ +& \log \left ( \; \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} \right ) - \frac{(9.5 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \\ +& \log \left ( \; \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} \right ) - \frac{(11 - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \\ \mathcal{L}(y;\mu,\delta^2) &= -3 \log(\delta) - \frac{3}{2} \log(2\pi) - \frac{1}{2\delta^2} \left [ (9-\mu)^2 + (9.5-\mu)^2 + (11-\mu)^2 \right] \end{aligned} $$

Now if we take derivate of the above equation with respect to $\mu$ and set the equation value to zero then we get the value of $\mu$ which gives us the maximum value of likelihood function.

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{1}{\delta^2} [9 + 9.5 + 11 - 3\mu] &= 0 \\ \mu &= \frac{9+9.5+11}{3} \\ \mu &= 9.833 \end{aligned} $$

Which fits our intuition of fitting a normal distribution to a dataset aligned with the average of the dataset.

Thus maximizing the likelihood function gives us the distribution parameter which fits the given data perfectly.

Maximizing likelihood in linear regression.¶

Here we will look at linear regression from probabilistic point of view which is show us by square of difference gives us the most likely hood that the prediction we do is closer to the actual value.

There are multiple probabilistic models which we can use to proof sum of square error, this is one of theme. In this probabilistic model we assume that our target/independent variable $Y$ is normally distributed, which would be true in multiple scenarios by the central limit theorem. Thus

$$ Y \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \delta^2) $$

where $\sim$ is a symbol to states distributed at and $\mathcal{N}(\mu, \delta^2)$ is symbol for normal distribution with mean $(\mu)$ and standard deviation $(\delta^2)$.

Now Consider that we have $n$ points, each of which is drawn in an independent and identically distributed way from the normal distribution from the above equation. For a given, $(\mu, \delta^2)$ the probability of those $n$ points being drawn define the likelihood function, which are just the multiplication of n normal probability density functions (PDF) because they are independent. Giving us the formula

$$ \mathcal{L}(\mu|Y) = \sum_{i=1}^n P_Y(y_i|\mu, \delta^2) = \sum_{i=1}^m \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-\frac{(y_i - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2}} $$

Because in our probabilistic model we have assume $Y$ to be normally distributed thus PMF for each $y^(i)$ would be same as the equation of normal curve.

Now our goal is to choose the unknown parameter $\mu$ (or $\delta^2$) which maximizes the likely hood. So we maximize the function $\mathcal{L}(\mu|Y)$ over the parameter $\mu$.

$$ \begin{aligned} \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \mathcal{L}(\mu|Y) = \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \sum_{i=1}^m \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-\frac{(y_i - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2}} \end{aligned} $$

Now maximizing the function is same as maximizing the log of the function. So,

$$ \begin{aligned} \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \; \mathcal{L}(\mu|Y) &= \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \; log \left ( \sum_{i=1}^m \frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}} e^{-\frac{(y_i - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2}} \right ) \\ &= \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \sum_{i=1}^m log \left (\frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}}\right ) + log \left( e^{-\frac{(y_i - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2}} \right ) \end{aligned} $$

The first term is constant so it wont have an effect in maximizing the outcome. So we can ignore the constant.

$$ \begin{aligned} \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \; \mathcal{L}(\mu|Y) &= \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \sum_{i=1}^m log \left (\frac{1}{\delta\sqrt{2\pi}}\right ) + log \left( e^{-\frac{(y_i - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2}} \right ) \\ &= \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \; \sum_{i=1}^m log \left( e^{-\frac{(y_i - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2}} \right ) \\ \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \; \mathcal{L}(\mu|Y) &= \sum_{i=1}^m -\frac{(y_i - \mu)^2}{2\delta^2} \end{aligned} $$

The right side of the equation is a negative number so the problem is same as minimizing the right side. So we can can write the following.

$$ \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{max}} \; \mathcal{L}(\mu|Y) = \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{min}} \sum_{i=1}^m (y_i - \mu)^2 $$

We can extend this further to our model of linear equation. Instead of assuming $Y$ to a normal distribution of mean $\mu$ we can write it as $Y$ being normally distributed with the means as a linear function of independent variable. With parameter $\theta$ that we are trying to find.

$$ Y \sim \mathcal{N}(\theta_0 + \theta_1X_1 + ... + \theta_mX_m, \; \delta^2) $$

Thus giving us the final equation as

$$ \begin{aligned} &= \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{min}} \sum_{i=1}^m (y_i - (\theta_0 + \theta_1X_1 + ... + \theta_mX_m))^2 \\ &= \underset{\mu}{\operatorname{arg}\,\operatorname{min}} \sum_{i=1}^m (y_i - h_{\theta}(x))^2 \end{aligned} $$

Thus proving that difference of square will give us most maximum likely hood when predicting $Y$ from a given set of independent variable.

Computing Linear Regression¶

Scikit Learn¶

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from sklearn import linear_model

CSV_FILE_PATH = '../../static/raw/notes/machine-learning/intro-to-machine-learning/stockprices.csv'

values_to_predict = np.array([400, 600, 512.35, 650.12]).reshape(-1, 1)

# Read CSV
training_data = pd.read_csv(CSV_FILE_PATH, delimiter='\t')

# Arrange data as required by scikit learn
X = training_data.amazon.to_numpy().reshape(-1, 1)
Y = training_data.google.to_numpy().reshape(-1, 1)

# Train model (No test data :P)
model = linear_model.LinearRegression()
model.fit(X, Y)
print('Model Information...')
print('Theta 0 / Slope = {}'.format(model.coef_[0][0]))
print('Theta 1/ Intercept = {}'.format(model.intercept_[0]))
print()

# Predict Value
predicted_values = model.predict(values_to_predict)

print('Predictions....')
for value, prediction in zip(values_to_predict, predicted_values):
    print('{} -> {}'.format(value[0], prediction[0]))

Model Information...
Theta 0 / Slope = 0.7759610940600332
Theta 1/ Intercept = 230.37023456964909

Predictions....
400.0 -> 540.7546721936624
600.0 -> 695.9468910056689
512.35 -> 627.9339011113071
650.12 -> 734.8380610399579

Locally weighted regression. (Loess / Lowess)¶

Locally weighted regression is a non-parametric, supervised, batch based learning algorithm. The idea behind locally weighted regression model is simple.

Consider a dataset as follows are we are trying to use linear regression model to bit the data.

As we can see the linear model wont fit the data perfectly. Event if we use a quadratic function the curve would only fit the first hump but it wont fit the straight line after that. We would have to use some combination of other mathematical function.

Another way to make a prediction for this type of dataset is as follows.

Instead of fitting the model to the entire dataset. We keep the training set always with us. And whenever we want to predict the target value for a given $x$. We take only the neighboring value of $Y$ from the training dataset and fit a linear model to it and then use it to predict the value to value of unknown $x$.

Thus fitting the model in the perfect way possible, but the downside is that we need access to all the training set when making prediction. So it is not considered a good algorithm for to work with large dataset.

Now we will look at how to do that mathematically.

We already now the cost function for simple linear regression.

$$ J(\theta) = \sum_{i=1}^m ( \; h_\theta(x^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \; )^2 $$

Now for locally weighted regression what we do is add a weight $(w)$ to the cost function. The points are which are further way from the point we are trying to predict get weight close to zero and the points close the the point we are trying to predict get a weight closer to 1. Thus our new cost function becomes as follows.

$$ J(\theta) = \sum_{i=1}^m w^{(i)} \; ( \; h_\theta(x^{(i)} - y^{(i)}) \; )^2 $$

Now we can choose any mathematical function for the weight but the general choose is of using a gaussian distribution or normal distribution. So the formula for weight becomes.

$$ w^{(i)} = exp \left ( - \frac{(x^{(i)} - x)^2}{2\tau^2} \right ) $$

Which is same as that of normal distribution. If we look at this function if the difference $(x^{(i)} - x)$ is small then the value of factor is close to zero, the value of $exp$ is close to $1$. And if the difference is larger the value of $exp$ will be close to $0$. Giving the local points higher weight then the further away points.

The graph of the weight function in our example will look something like this.

Where the red curve shows the weight function.

The Tau $(\tau)$ in the formula is a parameter we use to control the bandwidth of the weights. Following graph shows the weight function for different values of $(\tau)$.

The algorithm remains same as that of linear regression and we minimize the new cost function.

Logistic Regression¶

Logistics regression is a regression algorithm used in classification. Instead of predicting a continuous value given a set of independent feature it return a probability of class the given unknown input instance can belong to.

Types of Logistics Regression¶

There are three types of logistic regression algorithm, based on the value it predict.

  • Binary (yes/no)
  • Multi (Cat, Dog, Sheep)
  • Ordinal (low, medium, high)

Introduction¶

Suppose we have following dataset.

And we are trying to predict if $Y=0$ or $Y=1$ given a value of $X$. And if we perform a simple linear regression, as shown in figure, we would get a very bad prediction.

To solve such kind of classification problem we need to change our hypothesis from prediction value to classifying if a target value belong to a particular class ($0$ or $1$ in our case).

So our target variable or our prediction must be either $0$ or $1$.

$$ h_{\theta}(X) \in \{0, 1\} $$

Sigmoid or Logistic function.¶

To convert a continuos prediction of a linear equation into a value between $0$ and $1$ we use the following function.

$$ g(z) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-z}} $$

The above function is called the Signoid function or the Logistic function. Given a real number $z \; (z \in \mathbb{R})$ it return a value close to $0$ if $z$ is small and return a value close to $1$ if $z$ is large. As seen from the graph of the function below.

Thus we represent our hypothesis as sigmoid function of the feature.

$$ h_{\theta}(X) = g(\theta^TX) = \frac{1}{1+e^{- \theta^TX}} $$

Cost function¶

Now we can derive the cost function of the hypothesis.If we look it probabilistically, we know that the outcome of the hypothesis will be either $0$ or $1$. So we can write the probability as follows.

$$ \begin{aligned} P(y=1 | X; \theta) &= h_{\theta}(X) \\ P(y=0 | X; \theta) &= 1 - h_{\theta}(X) \\ \end{aligned} $$

Which states that the probability of $Y=1$ given $X$ parametrized on $\theta$ is $h_{\theta}(X)$ and by property of normalization of probability the probability of $Y=0$ is $1-h_{\theta}(X)$.

We can combine the above equation into a single equation as follows.

$$ P(Y|X;\theta) = h_{\theta}(x)^y \;\; (1 -h_{\theta}(x))^{1-y} $$

The above equation is same as the first one because when $y=1$, then the second equation become raise to $0$ which is one and the equation becomes $h_{\theta}(x)$. And when y=0 the first equation becomes raise to zero and becomes $1$ and the equation become $1 -h_{\theta}(x)$.

Now if we take the likely hood of the hypothesis to get value of $Y$ we get.

$$ \begin{aligned} \mathcal{L}(\theta) &= \sum_i P(y^{(i)}|x^{(i)};\theta) \\ &= \sum_i h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})^{y^{(i)}} \;\; (1 -h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}))^{1-y^{(i)}} \end{aligned} $$

Now maximizing the function is same as maximizing the log of the function of we take log on the right and we get.

$$ \mathcal{L}(\theta) = \sum_i y^{(i)} \; log( h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})) + (1-y^{(i)}) \; log(1 -h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})) $$

So the function becomes our cost function and we want to maximize the likely hood of by choosing parameter $(\theta)$.

Gradient Accent¶

We use the same gradient descent algorithm as the one we used in linear regression but our goal here is not to decrease the cost function, we need to increase the cost function (likely hood). Instead of subtracting the derivative of the cost function with $\theta$ we add the derivative to it. This approach is also called as gradient accent. Thus our gradient accent formula will become.

$$ \theta := \theta + \alpha \frac{\delta}{\delta \theta} \mathcal{L}(\theta) $$

Where $\alpha$ is our learning rate similar to the linear regression.

Now we find the partial derivative of the likely hood function.

$$ \begin{aligned} \frac{\delta}{\delta \theta} \mathcal{L}(\theta) &= \frac{\delta}{\delta \theta} \sum_i y^{(i)} \; log( h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})) + (1-y^{(i)}) \; log(1 -h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})) \\ \end{aligned} $$

By chain rule.

$$ \begin{aligned} &= \sum_i y^{(i)} \; \frac{1}{h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})} \; ( \; h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) \; (1 - h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})) \; ) x^{(i)} \\ &+ (1-y^{(i)}) \; \frac{1}{(1 -h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})} \; (-1) \; ( \; (h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) \; (1 - h_{\theta}(x^{(i)})\;) \; x^{(i)}) \\ &= \sum_i y^{(i)} \; (1 - h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) ) \; x^{(i)} + (1-y^{(i)}) \; (-1) \; h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) \; x^{(i)} \\ &= \sum_i y^{(i)} x^{(i)} - y^{(i)} h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) x^{(i)} - h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) x^{(i)} + y^{(i)} h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) x^{(i)} \\ &= \sum_i y^{(i)} x^{(i)} - h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) x^{(i)} \\ \frac{\delta}{\delta \theta} \mathcal{L}(\theta) &= \sum_i ( \; y^{(i)} - h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) \; ) x^{(i)} \\ \end{aligned} $$

Thus giving us the derivative for the cost function of logistic regression. The derivate is symbolically similar to that of linear regression but the difference is the formula for the $h_{\theta}(X)$. The similarly is explore more in the concept of generalized linear regression model.

Rest of the algorithm is same as linear regression.

Newton's method¶

Another way of solving logistic regression is by using newtons method. To understand this method we will first understand newton's method on a normal function.

Suppose we have a function $f(x)$ as shown in image above and we want to find the value of $x$ where $f(x)=0$. We can find the value of $x$ by following the algorithm stated below.

First we choose a random value of $x$, $X0$ in our example/figure. And we find the value of the function at $X0$ i.e $f(X0)$. Then we take derivative at $f(X0)$ to get the tangent to the function at the point $f(X0)$. The tangent will touch our $x$-axis at some point let's name it $X1$. Then we can define the slop of the tangent with following equation.

$$ f\prime(X0) = \frac{f(X0)}{\Delta} $$

where $f\prime(X0)$ is the derivative of function $f(x)$ at $X0$. And since the slop of the line is given by $\frac{rise}{step}$. We get the above equation.

We can rearrange the equation to get the value of delta.

$$ \Delta = \frac{f\prime(X0)}{f(X0)} $$

We can generalize this equation for any $x_i$.

$$ \Delta = \frac{f\prime(x_i)}{f(x_i)} $$

Thus the next value of any $x_{i+1}$ can be computed by following equation.

$$ x_{i+1} = x_i - \frac{f\prime(x_i)}{f(x_i)} $$

Newton's method for logistic regression¶

We can use the above equation for logistic regression. In logistic regression we want to maximize the likelihood function $\mathcal{L}(\theta)$ which is same as substituting the value of value of its derivative to zero $\mathcal{L}\prime(\theta) = 0$. Thus to find the value of $\theta$ where $\mathcal{L}\prime(\theta)=0$ we use the newton's method. Where our $f(x)$ equals to $\mathcal{L}\prime(\theta)$. Thus our equation for finding the next best possible value for $\theta$ is given as.

$$ \theta_{i+1} = \theta_i - \frac{\mathcal{L}\prime(\theta)}{\mathcal{L}\prime\prime(\theta)} $$

The above equation works only for one parameter $\theta_i$ but if we have multiple parameter we use the vector $\theta$ and the equation becomes.

$$ \theta^{(t+1)} = \theta^{(t)} - H^{-1} \Delta_{\theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta) $$

Where $\Delta_{\theta}\mathcal{L}(\theta)$ is the derivate of the likelihood function. And the $H$ is the matrix called as Hession Matrix where,

$$ H_{i,j} = \frac{\delta^2 \mathcal{L}}{\delta\theta_i\delta\theta_j} $$

Newton's method for logistic regression converse really faster than the normal gradient descent. But the downside is the we need to first commute the hession matrix with is of $n\times n$ matrix where $n$ is the number of feature and every iterator we need to calculate the matrix and then take the inverse of it which is really a costly operation. So newton's method work really well on smaller dataset.

Computing Logistics Regression¶

Scikit learn¶

import random
import numpy as np
from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression


# Get iris data
X, Y = load_iris(return_X_y=True)

# Create model
model = LogisticRegression(random_state=0, solver='lbfgs', multi_class='multinomial', max_iter=150).fit(X, Y)

# make prediction - From test only :P
test_data = np.array(random.choices(X, k=5))
print('Test Data: ')
print(test_data)
print()

predictions = model.predict(test_data)
print('Prediction of classes: {}'.format(predictions))

Test Data: 
[[5.4 3.4 1.5 0.4]
 [5.  3.3 1.4 0.2]
 [5.8 2.7 4.1 1. ]
 [5.8 2.7 5.1 1.9]
 [5.6 3.  4.5 1.5]]

Prediction of classes: [0 0 1 2 1]

Regularization of model¶

When we use linear regression method to fit our training dataset there usually two before arises.

  • Overfitting training dataset.
  • If multiple parameters are present then the model becomes complex.

Other name of the above problems is bias (overfitting) and variance (using features which are correlated to each other, thus adding noise without adding information). The diagram below give an idea about it.

As we can see we need to reduce bias and variance. To solve these two problem we add a penalty to the cost function. This prevents gradient decent from optimizing the $(\theta)$ to much to add bias and variance.

Lasso Regression / Variance Regularization / L1 Regularization.¶

One way of controlling the variance is to add the following to the cost function of the linear regression.

$$ J(\theta) = \frac{1}{2M} \sum_{i=0}^M (h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2 + \lambda \sum_{i=0}^M |\theta^{(i)}| $$

The penalty added to the cost function is the absolute sum of all the $\theta$. And $(\lambda)$ is the controlling factor. If $(\lambda)$ is zero then the equation is same as that of linear regression. The higher we make the $(\lambda)$ the higher the cost function get and the gradient decent algorithm tries to make the $\theta$ close to zero. So my controlling the value of $\theta$ we can control how many variable/feature can contribute in the model.

The name L1 Regularization comes from linear algebra (L1 Norm and L2 Norm). They are different ways of measure the length of the vector. $L1$ norm or also called Manhattan Distance is a way of calculating the length of the vector by taking absolute sum of its component . For example for vector $\bar{V}=[3,-4]$ magnitude will be $|3|+|-4|=7$. And L2 Regularization (seen below) also called as Euclidean norm is a way of calculating magnitude of vector by taking square root of sum of square of components $\sqrt{(3)^2 + (-4)} = \sqrt{25} = 5$.

Ridge Regression / Bias Regularization / L2 Regularization.¶

One way of controlling bias is to add following to the cost function.

$$ J(\theta) = \frac{1}{2M} \sum_{i=0}^M (h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2 + \lambda \sum_{i=0}^M (\theta^{(i)})^2 $$

Same as lasso regression we can control the bias by controlling the $(\lambda)$. This constraint results in minimized coefficients (aka shrinkage) that trend towards zero the larger the value of $\lambda$. Shrinking the coefficients leads to a lower variance and in turn a lower error value. Therefore Ridge regression decreases the complexity of a model but does not reduce the number of variables, it rather just shrinks their effect.

Elastic Net¶

We can combine both of the regularization withing one regularization named as Elastic Net, which gives the cost function as follows.

$$ J(\theta) = \frac{1}{2M} \sum_{i=0}^M (h_{\theta}(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2 + \lambda \left ( \frac{1-\alpha}{2}\sum_{i=0}^M (\theta^{(i)})^2 + \alpha \sum_{i=0}^M |\theta^{(i)}| \right ) $$

In addition to setting and choosing a $\lambda$ value elastic net also allows us to tune the $\alpha$ parameter where $\alpha = 0$ corresponds to ridge and $\alpha = 1$ to lasso. Simply put, if you plug in 0 for $\alpha$, the penalty function reduces to the L1 (ridge) term and if we set $\alpha$ to 1 we get the L2 (lasso) term. Therefore we can choose an alpha value between 0 and 1 to optimize the elastic net. Effectively this will shrink some coefficients and set some to 0 for sparse selection.

Decision Tree¶

Decision tree are one of the simplest and most useful machine learning algorithm. The good of decision tree is it ability to represent the learned knowledge in a human understandable manner.

Decision tree can we used for classification as well as regression.

Suppose we have following dataset. - Link

Outlook Temp Humidity Windy Play Golf
Rainy Hot High False No
Rainy Hot High True No
Overcast Hot High False Yes
Sunny Mild High False Yes
Sunny Cool Normal False Yes
Sunny Cool Normal True No
Overcast Cool Normal True Yes
Rainy Mild High False No
Rainy Cool Normal False Yes
Sunny Mild Normal False Yes
Rainy Mild Normal True Yes
Overcast Mild High True Yes
Overcast Hot Normal False Yes
Sunny Mild High True No

And our goal is to predict wether we will play golf based on the weather condition. To do so we can build a decision tree as follows.

Here we drill down the decision tree starting from the root node (Outlook) and follow the tree until we reach the leaf node which gives out decision (target value). For example, for the first row in our dataset, we look at the Outlook column/feature. It is Rainy and then we go down the branch from root to the branch which is marked as Rainy. Then we check the Humidity column/feature, is it normal or high?. In our case it is High so we go down the branch and reach our leaf node denoted in yellow Play (No). This is how we can use decision tree for classification.

To more formally define decision tree. A decision tree is a tree where each node represents a feature(attribute), each link(branch) represents a decision(rule) and each leaf represents an outcome(categorical or continues value).

There internal nodes are called the Decision nodes and the leaf nodes are called the prediction nodes.

Building Decision Tree¶

We have seen how to use decision tree, but how do we build it given a dataset. We can write a pseudocode which outlines the process of building a decision tree. The code is as follows.

Algorithm BuildSubtree
Require: Node n, and Data D.

n->split, DataLeft, DataRight = FindBestSplit(D)

if StoppingCriteria(DataLeft) is True then:
    n -> left = FindPrediction(DataLeft)
else:
    BuildSubtree(n.left, DataLeft)

if StoppingCriteria(DataRight) is True then:
    n -> right = FindPrediction(DataRight)
else:
    BuildSubtree(n.right, DataRight)

In the algorithm BuildSubtree we start with with a root Node $n$ and data $D$. Then we find the best rule which will help us split the data which can help us prefect the target value better with the function FindBestSplit. It returns the splitting rule and left and right data.

Then how we do decide that when should we stop splitting the node into more child nodes and make a decision. For that we use StoppingCriteria function. If we have meet the criteria we make a prediction/leaf node with function FindPrediction function or else we recursively build the tree.

Now we will look into each of the function FindBestSplit, StoppingCriteria and FindPrediction individually.

Finding the best split.¶

The goal of the function FindBestSplit is to find the best feature in the dataset and the best value of that feature that split the data into two sub datasets such that each dataset belongs to a single class.

But what is a good feature to split and a bad feature to split. A good feature is the one when used to split the data generate a homogeneous dataset with the same class/target value.

Now to actually mathematically measure which feature divides the data in a good homogeneous dataset we can use two measurements mainly Information Gain or Gini Index.

Information Gain¶

One way of selecting the best feature to split with is to select the feature which when used to split the data gives us the most information about the data. In other words we can say that if a dataset is homogeneous then we have very high information about the data, that is if we pick any random element from the dataset we can tell for sure which class it belongs to. And if the data is heterogenous with each class having the same probability then we know very less about the data and thus our information if very less about the data.

Now to calculate the information about our data we use a negative approach. We calculate the randomness of the data. The more random the data the less information we have about the dataset.

Shannon Entropy¶

To measure the randomness about the data we use something called as the Shannon Entropy. Entropy being defined as the "measure of randomness" or the "measure of information". Because the more randomness we have the less information we have about the dataset and the via versa.

Shannon Entropy was defined for information theory. So we will first look that what it meant in information sense and the try to link it with our machine learning/statistical model.

Let's Suppose we encode all the smaller letter alphabets of English language $X = \{ a, b, c, ..., z \}$ in bits. To encode $n=26$ characters we will need $log_2(26)=4.7 \approx 5$, $5$ bits where $a=00000, b=00001$ etc.

So in general we if we have $n$ symbols to encode we would would need following numbers of bits to encode it.

$$ log_2(n) $$

We can covert the above equation from information domain to statical domain as follows. Instead of thinking of encoding each symbol we can thing ok picking any $i^{th}$ symbol from the set $X$ with probability $p_i$. So we can rewrite the about equation in statical context as follows.

$$ log_2(n) = log \left (\frac{1}{p_i} \right ) = log(1) - log(p_i) = - log(p_i) $$

The probability of a character/symbol will not evenly distributed. In English for example the vowels have a high probability of appearing than the consonants. So to find the expected number of bits (denoted by $H$) we can use the following.

$$ H((p_1, p_2, ..., p_n3)) = E[-log(p_i)] = - \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i log(p_i) $$

This giving us the formula for the entropy, denoted by $H_X$ .

$$ \text{Entropy} = H_X = E[-log(p_i)] = - \sum_{i=1}^{n} p_i log(p_i) $$

The above equation will have the maximum value when all the $p_i$ as equal value. ie. $(p_1, p_2, ... , p_n) = \frac{1}{n}$. And entropy will be lowest when only one $p_i$ has a value of $1$, converting the equation to $log(1) = 1$.

Following graph shows the value of entropy.

As we can see from the graph that the entropy is at its maximum when the probability equals to $0.5$, that is there is a $50\%$ chance that a particular element belongs to a particular class. And the entropy is at its lowest when the probability is either $0$ which all the element in the dataset does not belong to the class or either $1$ which means all the elements in the dataset belong to the given class.

Joint Entropy¶

The joint entropy of two variables $X$ and $Y$ with joint probability $(\; p(X, Y) = p(A \cup B) \; )$ is given as.

$$ H(X, Y) = -E[log(\; p(X, Y) \; )] = - \sum_{x \in X} \sum_{y \in Y} p(x, y) log(\; p(x, y) \; ) $$
Conditional Entropy¶

Conditional Entropy between two variables is given as follow.

$$ H(Y | X) = - E[log( \; p(Y | X) \; )] = - \sum_{x \in X} \sum_{y \in Y} p(x, y) log(\; p(y | x) \; ) $$

Now if we consider joint entropy and conditional entropy together we get the following relation.

$$ \begin{align} H(X, Y) &= - \sum_{x \in X} \sum_{y \in Y} p(x, y) log(\; p(X, Y) \; ) \\ &= - \sum_{x \in X} \sum_{y \in Y} p(x, y) log(\; p(x) p(y|x) \; ) \tag{definition of conditional probability}\\ &= - \sum_{x \in X} \sum_{y \in Y} p(x, y) log(\; p(x) \; ) - \sum_{x \in X} \sum_{y \in Y} p(x, y) log(\; p(y|x) \; ) \tag{log of products}\\ &= - \sum_{x \in X} p(x) log(\; p(x) \; ) - \sum_{x \in X} \sum_{y \in Y} p(x, y) log(\; p(y|x) \; ) \tag{definition of marginal probability} \\ H(X, Y) &= H(X) + H(Y|X) \end{align} $$
Gain¶

Now we have a measure of information/impurity of a dataset we can use this to decide which feature to use to split the dataset. We choose the feature which give us more information of the data. To do so we use the following equation.

$$ \begin{aligned} \text{Information Gain}(X) &= Entropy(D) - Entropy(D, X) \\ &= H(D) - H(D, X) \\ I(X) &= H(D) - H(D | X) \end{aligned} $$

This equation is called the information gain. We simply find the difference between the entropy of the dataset and the entropy of the dataset after the split. And our goal is to maximize the information gain.

So we calculate the information gain for all the feature and choose the feature which gives us the maximum information gain.

Gini Index / Gini Coefficient / Gini Ratio¶

Another way to thinking about split the data is thinking of making the data pure. A pure dataset is a dataset where all the element belong to a single class. One way of computing the impurity of the dataset is to calculate the Gini index. Gini index gives us a value between $0$ and $1$ where $0$ means all the element belong to a single class and $1$ means all elements belong to different classes.

The formula for Gini index is given as follows.

$$ \text{Gini Index} = 1 - \sum_x p(X)^2 $$

Where $X$ denotes every class/target that we are trying to classify and $p(x)$ denotes the probability that if we pick a random element from the dataset it will belong to that class/target $x$.

The above equation will give $0$ when only one class has the highest probability $(1)$ and others have zero probability. And otherwise Gini Index will be greater than $0$.

To understand the derivate we need to look at an example. Suppose we have an experiment of picking up two binary variable whose values can be either $0$ or $1$. And let $p(X=0)$ be the probability fo variable being $1$ and let $p(X=1)$ be the probability of variable being $0$. And each event of picking the variable is independent. Then we have following equation.

$$ \begin{aligned} p(X=0)p(X=0)+ p(X=0)p(X=1) + p(X=1)p(X=0) + p(X=1)p(X=1) &= 1 \end{aligned} $$

Now in the above equation if we consider $X=1$ as one class and $X=0$ as other class. Then $p(X=0)p(X=1)$ and $p(X=1)p(X=0)$ is impure data and $p(X=0)p(X=0)$ and $p(X=1)p(X=1)$ is pure dataset as they belong to single class $0$ or $1$. So to calculate the probability of impure data we can do the following.

$$ \begin{aligned} p(X=0)p(X=1) + p(X=1)p(X=0) &= 1 - p(X=0)p(X=0) - p(X=1)p(X=1) \\ &= 1 - p(X=0)^2 - p(X=1)^2 \\ &= 1 - \sum_x p(X=x)^2 \end{aligned} $$

Thus giving us the formula of Gini index which measure the probability of impurities in a given dataset.

We can use Gini index to split the dataset. We find the feature which gives the least Gini index and then use that feature to split the dataset.

Chai Square¶

Another way of finding the best split is to use the Chi test of independence to find the best feature to split the data with. We choose the feature which have a high correlation with the target variable. So in other words we choose the feature which have a high dependency on the target variable.

Stopping Criteria¶

Now we know how to split the tree using information gain or the gini index. But when should be decided to stop splitting the tree into further nodes. There are multiple options, two of them are listed below.

When the leaf is pure¶

We can stop splitting the tree when after the last split we have reached a dataset which is pure (every element belong to the same classes/target value). We can calculate the purity of the dataset using the Gini Index.

When we have # number of samples.¶

Other stopping criteria could be we keep splitting the tree until a only a certain number of element are left in the final split dataset.

In practice the combination of both is used. Purity check to save commutation and number of samples check to prevent overfitting.

Finding prediction for leaf node.¶

Make predication/leaf node is as easy as finding the most common class/target value in the sample and create a leaf node out of it. So whenever a new sample reaches the leaf node the predicate class will be used to make predication of the unseen data.

Algorithms¶

There are multiple algorithm which uses the concepts we discussed above to build a decision tree.

ID3 Algorithm¶

ID3 (Iterative Dichotomiser 3) algorithm was developed by J.R Quinlan. It follows a top down greedy search approach to build a decision tree. ID3 uses Entropy and information gain to build the tree.

The algorithm is simple for each parent node, including the root node. Calculate the entropy for each feature and then choose the feature which give the highest information gain. And the split using that feature. The parent will have same number of child as the number of unique classes in the selected feature. Repeat this for the subtree as well. And stop when we there are no feature to select from or one on the above stopping criteria is met.

For above dataset the algorithm will follow setps something like this.

1) Calculate the Entropy of the dataset.

2) Calculate entropy of single feature. Example of outlook feature is given below.

3) Then calculate information gain for each feature $E(S) - E(T,X)$ and choose the feature with highest information gain. Outlook in this case.

4) Split the tree using the best feature

5) Stop if dataset is pure of minimum number of samples has reached.

CART Algorithm / Gini Index Algorithm¶

CART or Gini index algorithm is same as that of ID3 algorithm. But instead of using information gain for choosing the best feature to split we use Gini index.

CHAID Algorithm¶

CHAID (Chi-square Automatic Interaction Detector) is a common algorithm used to build a decision tree by finding the most correlated feature with respect to the target variable. It uses the Chi-square test of independence to find the most correlated feature with respect to the target variable.

The steps of the algorithm is simple.

1) Pick a level of significant $(\alpha)$. 2) Pick on feature from the dataset. 3) Find the chi square for combination of values of the feature with respect to the target variable. 4) Pick the combination with the largest p-value and merge the values. 5) Repeat steps 3 to 4 until there are no more combination or chi-square value of every combination is smaller than $\alpha$. 6) Repeat step 2 to 5 for every feature. 7) Select the feature with the smallest p-value as the feature to split on.

Lets take an example, suppose we have a dataset with two nominal features $X1$ and $X2$ and a target nominal variable $Y$.

And lets suppose we have following frequency count data with respect to the feature.

Now first we select the first feature $X1$ and find chi-square for every combinations of values of $X1$ with respect to $Y$.

The algorithm then identifies the pair of categories of $X1 with largest p-value above and compares this p-value to the $\approx$ (0.05 in our case).

In this example, this is the pair defined by categories $3$ and $4$ of $X1$. Since the p-value for this pair (0.2143) is greater than $\alpha$, the two categories are merged to form a single compound category. As a result, a new set of categories of $X1$ is formed, and the same analysis is repeated for the new merged category.

Again, the pair that results in the largest p-value greater than $\alpha = 0.05$ is merged. Here this corresponds to merging category 2 with the compound category 3,4. If further mergers were possible, this process would continue. However, since there are now only two (merged) categories remaining for $X1$, the merging process stops.

The algorithm now calculates an adjusted p-value for the set of merged categories of X1 and the categories of Y using a Bonferroni adjustment.

The Bonferroni method is a simple technique for controlling the overall probability of a false significant result when multiple comparisons are to be carried out. When conducting multiple analyses on the same dependent variable, the chance of committing a Type I error increases, thus increasing the likelihood of coming about a significant result by pure chance. To correct for this, or protect from Type I error, a Bonferroni correction is conducted.To get the Bonferroni corrected/adjusted p value, divide the original α-value by the number of analyses on the dependent variable.

Thus the formula for Bonferroni adjustment is given as follows.

$$ B = \sum_{i=0}^{r-1} (-1)^i \frac{(r-i)^c}{i!(r-i)!} $$

where $c$ is the number of original categories and $r$ is the number of categories left after merging.

After multiplying the Bonferroni correction we get a adjusted p-value of $0.0311 (= 0.00448843 × 7)$

Now we repeat the same step for $X2$.

The adjusted p-value in this case is $1$ (since $0.5985587 × 3$ is greater than $1$).

The final step is to split the node on the basis of that “merged explanator with smallest adjusted p-value less than $\alpha = 0.05$. Here this means we split the root node into two subnodes on the basis of the merged categories of $X1$. That is, one subnode contains the $35$ cases with $X1 = 1$ while the other contains the remaining $65$ cases with $X1 = 2, 3 , 4$.

We continue building the tree until we reach a stopping criteria.

Computing Decision Tree¶

scikit learn¶

import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier, export_graphviz
from sklearn.preprocessing import OrdinalEncoder, LabelEncoder
from graphviz import Source
from IPython.display import SVG, display

# Read Data
data = pd.read_csv('../../static/raw/notes/machine-learning/intro-to-machine-learning/decision_tree_golf.csv')

# Get features and target variable
features = data.drop('Play Golf', axis=1)
classes = data['Play Golf']

# Enocde nomimal features
feature_encoder = OrdinalEncoder()
X = feature_encoder.fit_transform(features)

classes_encoder = LabelEncoder()
Y = classes_encoder.fit_transform(classes)

# Split data intro traning and test
X_train, X_test, Y_train, Y_test = train_test_split(X, Y, test_size=0.2, random_state=42)

# Build the tree
tree = DecisionTreeClassifier()
tree.fit(X_train, Y_train)

# Classify using the tree
predictions = tree.predict(X_test)

print(f'Test Dataset: {Y_test}')
print(f'Predictions: {predictions}')
print()

# Display Tree
tree_display = Source(export_graphviz(tree, out_file=None
   , feature_names=['Outlook','Temp','Humidity','Windy'], class_names=['Yes', 'No'] 
   , filled = True))

print('Tree.')
display(SVG(tree_display.pipe(format='svg')))

Test Dataset: [1 1 0]
Predictions: [1 1 0]

Tree.

Regression Tree¶

We have seen the use of decision tree to build a tree which can be used in building a classification tree. The output of decision tree was discrete class for a given set of unknown features. We can use regression tree for predicting continuous variables as well.

The algorithm of building the tree is same as we did in that of decision tree. We choose the node and splitting criteria such that related node will be grouped together. At the leave node we make prediction for the target variable by either taking the average of the dataset at the nodes or by building a linear regression model to the dataset at the leaf nodes.

Regression tree vs Linear Regression¶

Benefits of regression tree.¶

  • Making Prediction is faster as no calculations are involved.
  • Easy to understand which parameter are important for making the prediction by visualizing the parameter hierarchy.
  • If some data is missing and we reach only to subpart of tree, we make take average of all leaf under that subtree to give a approx prediction.
  • Can work with both categorical and continuos data.

Disadvantage of regression tree.¶

  • Single regression trees have high variance, resulting in unstable predictions (an alternative subsample of training data can significantly change the terminal nodes). Due to the high variance single regression trees have poor predictive accuracy.

Algorithm¶

The same algorithm that we used to building a decision tree can be used for building the regression tree. Here are some extra algorithms that we can use.

Standard Deviation Reduction¶

Suppose we have to following data. And our goal is to find the best estimate of our target value.

Then we split our dataset such that the standard deviation in the dataset reduces and hence the name. So do that first we need to calculate the standard deviation of the target variable.

We can see total number of items are $n=14$. Means and standard deviation for our target variable are $\bar{x}=39.8$ and $S=9.32$ respectively.

We also calculate the Coefficient of Variation which is the percentage of standard deviation and mean. It gives how much data is spread from the means for a given dataset. We used coefficient of variance as stopping criteria to prevent tree from overfitting, one example of stopping criteria would be to stop spilting if the coefficient of variation is below $10\%$.

Now we calculate the standard deviation of the target variable with respect to every other attribute. We do that by using the following formulate.

$$ S(T, X) = \sum_{c \in X} P(c)S(c) $$

Where $T$ is the target variable, $X$ is a feature and $P(c)$ is the probability of the value in that feature and $S(C)$ is the standard deviation of the feature.

For example to calculate the standard deviation between the target value and the feature outlook we do the following calculation.

Then we find the Standard Deviation Reduction by subtracting the original standard deviation between the feature and the target. In our example the standard deviation reduction for the outlook feature will be.

$$ \begin{aligned} SDR(T, X) &= S(T) - S(T, X) \\ SDR(Hours, Outlook) &= 9.32 - 7.66 \\ SDR(Hours, Outlook) &= 1.66 \end{aligned} $$

We do this for every feature and find the feature which gives the greatest reduction in standard deviation.

As we can see the outlook feature given the most reduction. So we choose the outlook feature and split the tree.

We repeat the same for sub dataset in the tree. We calculate the coefficient of variation on the dataset and see if we have reached the stopping point in splitting.

As we can see for the outcast branch we have reached our threshold of $10\%$ coefficient of variation. Then we create a leaf node under outcast branch and make a prediction of the target variable by taking the average of the target variable.

We continue this to build the entire tree.
